title: Broadway Tunnel (Los Angeles)
text:
The Broadway Tunnel was a <a href="tunnel">tunnel</a> under <a href="Fort%20Moore">Fort Moore Hill</a> in <a href="Downtown%20Los%20Angeles">Downtown Los Angeles, California</a>. It extended <a href="Broadway%20%28Los%20Angeles%29">North Broadway</a> (formerly Fort Street), at Sand Street (later California Street), one block north of <a href="Temple%20Street%20%28Los%20Angeles%29">Temple Street</a>, northeast to the intersection of Bellevue Avenue (later <a href="Sunset%20Boulevard">Sunset Boulevard</a>, now <a href="Cesar%20Chavez%20Avenue">Cesar Chavez Avenue</a>), to Buena Vista Street (now North Broadway).
History.
The proposal for opening <a href="Broadway%20%28Los%20Angeles%29">Broadway</a> through to Buena Vista Street, and extending the street south into what was then part of <a href="Main%20Street%20%28Los%20Angeles%29">Main Street</a>, below <a href="Los%20Angeles%20streets%2C%201-10%23">Tenth Street</a>, in order to give a continuous, wide <a href="thoroughfare">thoroughfare</a> from the southern <a href="city%20limits">city limits</a> to the <a href="East%20Los%20Angeles%20%28region%29">Eastside</a>, was made as early as February 1891.
Plans were prepared by the <a href="civil%20engineering">city engineer</a>'s office in early March 1895. The main argument for its construction was that a tunnel providing an additional opening on the north would decrease the constantly increasing <a href="traffic">traffic</a> (horses, buggies and wagons), which was causing a dangerous <a href="traffic%20congestion">jam</a> at the corner of <a href="1st%20Street%20%28Los%20Angeles%29">First</a> and <a href="Spring%20Street%20Financial%20District">Spring Streets</a>.
Construction.
Work began on the Broadway Tunnel on November 2, 1899. About 25 men with <a href="team">team</a>s (of animals) moved obstructions out of the way in preparation for the excavation, from the north approach. On the morning of January 20, 1900, a laborer was buried under about 20 tons of earth at the north end of the tunnel. The wood bracing fell over the man in such a manner that he was saved from being crushed to death.
The tunnel required more than 50,000 <a href="cubic%20yard">cubic yard</a>s (38 227.75 m3) of <a href="elevation">elevation</a>, 4,000 cubic yards (3 058.22 m3) of <a href="concrete">concrete</a> and 1.25 million of <a href="brickwork">bricks</a> to line it. With the exception of the tunnel in <a href="Fairmount%20Park">Fairmount Park</a> in <a href="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a>, which was in <a href="diameter">diameter</a>, but only long, the Broadway Tunnel was the widest tunnel of its type in the U.S., and possibly in the world, at that time. According to an article in the "<a href="Los%20Angeles%20Times">Los Angeles Times</a>", the Third Street Tunnel, which was also nearing completion at the time, could have been put inside the Broadway Tunnel leaving enough room for a <a href="sidewalk">sidewalk</a> wide.
The Broadway Tunnel was completed and opened for traffic on Saturday, August 17, 1901. It was long, wide and high, with a <a href="grade%20%28slope%29">grade</a> of 6 in 100, falling toward the east. The cost in its construction was $66,000.
Reconstruction.
The Broadway Tunnel was closed for reconstruction in 1915. The roadway was lowered to decrease the grade, wood block flooring was installed to provide a noiseless surface for the traffic of teams and <a href="automobile">automobile</a>s, and a false roof built inside the original shell. Because of the lowering, it was necessary to make a <a href="cut%20%28earthmoving%29">cut</a> of in California Street, and to change the grade of North Broadway from Temple Street to the tunnel. The concrete <a href="arch">arch</a>way of the Broadway Tunnel was high, and the entire bore was lined with white <a href="Ceramic%20tile">glazed tile</a>. The <a href="stairway">stairway</a> on the outer face of the southern <a href="portal%20%28architecture%29">portal</a> was extended to a rise of to Fort Moore Hill.
The work was completed and the Broadway Tunnel reopened in early February 1916. Due to the importance of the <a href="arterial%20road">artery</a> of travel, through which thousands of automobiles, teams and <a href="pedestrian">pedestrian</a>s would be passing daily, an event was held on Saturday, February 19, formally turning the tunnel over to the city, with the <a href="Automobile%20Club%20of%20Southern%20California">Automobile Club of Southern California</a> in charge.
Closure.
The Broadway Tunnel was closed on June 2, 1949. It was demolished for the construction of the new <a href="U.S.%20Route%20101%20in%20California">Hollywood Freeway</a> (U.S. Route 101) through Downtown. The route cut through Fort Moore Hill and made it necessary for a Broadway <a href="overpass">overpass</a> to be built across the freeway at the former Broadway Tunnel site.
